questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following opioids has maximum plasma protein binding capacity?
questions.explanation: Sufentanil has maximum plasma protein binding capacity. More than 90% of sufentanil is bound to alpha acid glycoprotein in plasma. Plasma protein binding capacity of opioids: • Sufentanil: 90% • Fentanyl: 80-85% • Pethidine (meperidine): 65-75% • Morphine: 36%

questions.question: Question 2: Which among the following is the most potent opioid analgesic?
questions.explanation: Sufentanil is the most potent opioid. It is 1000 times more potent than morphine. On the other hand, fentanyl is around 100 times more potent than morphine.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following has the most rapid analgesic action?
questions.explanation:
The most rapid analgesic action is achieved by remifentanil. Analgesic action (peak) is achieved within 1 to 1.5 min following intravenous administration. Analgesic action- duration for peak action: • Remifentanil: 1 to 1.5 min • Fentanyl: 5 min • Sufentanil: 5 min • Meperidine: 15 min 380 
Sold by @itachibot The rapid onset of action and the rapid recovery (within 15 min) owing to metabolism by plasma 
esterases of remifentanil make it an ideal analgesic for short painful procedures.

questions.question:
Question 4: A middle-aged man with liver metastasis and altered LFT is posted for a surgery. What would 
be the opioid of choice in him?
questions.explanation:
Opioid of choice in patients with compromised hepatic function is remifentanil. Remifentanil is hydrolyzed by plasma and tissue esterases and hence its metabolism is 
independent of hepatic function. Other opioids like fentanyl, alfentanil, and sufentanil are metabolized by the liver.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 48-year-old woman with CKD is scheduled for a surgery. Her serum creatinine is 2.4mg/dL 
and eGFR is 13. Which of the following opioids can be safely used in her?
questions.explanation:
The given lab values in a CKD patient are suggestive of renal failure and remifentanil can be safely 
used in renal failure patients. Remifentanil is hydrolyzed by plasma and tissue esterases. The pharmacokinetics and the 
pharmacodynamics of remifentanil are not altered by renal dysfunction. Option A: Pethidine is metabolized to norpethidine, accumulation of which can lead to CNS 
excitatory effects (seizures). Option C: High levels of alfentanil can lead to prolonged action. Option D: Morphine is metabolized to morphine-6-glucuronide which can accumulate leading to 
respiratory depression. Note: Fentanyl clearance is not altered by renal failure but its plasma protein binding is decreased 
which can alter the concentration of the free drug. Hence, fentanyl is the second drug of choice 
after remifentanil.

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient who underwent an intra-abdominal surgery is about to receive intraspinal opioid 
injection for analgesia. Which of the following drugs should not be used for this purpose?
questions.explanation:
Remifentanil should not be used for intraspinal injection. Remifentanil is formulated in combination with glycine. Glycine acts as an inhibitory 
neurotransmitter in the spinal dorsal horn that causes a reversible motor weakness when it is 
injected intrathecally. For this reason, remifentanil is not approved for spinal or epidural use.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is the shortest acting opioid?
questions.explanation:
The shortest acting opioid is remifentanil with t1/2 of 8-20 minutes. 381 
Sold by @itachibot The rapid metabolism by tissue esterases and rapid clearance results in its ultra short-acting 
nature. Remifentanil has the fastest onset of action and recovery, making it the opioid of choice in 
daycare surgery.

questions.question: Question 8: Which among the following is not included in neuroleptic anesthesia?
questions.explanation:
Propofol is not included in neuroleptic anesthesia. Neuroleptic anesthesia includes fentanyl, droperidol, and nitrous oxide. Neuroleptic analgesia includes fentanyl and droperidol. Neuroleptic anesthesia is characterized by analgesia, the absence of clinically apparent motor 
activity, suppression of autonomic reflexes, maintenance of cardiovascular stability, and amnesia. QT interval prolongation and torsades de pointes due to droperidol have made this technique 
obsolete.

questions.question:
Question 9: You are planning to use a transdermal patch for one of your patients who require 
around-the-clock opioids for his cancer pain. Which of the following drugs will you prescribe?
questions.explanation:
Fentanyl is available as a transdermal patch and can be prescribed to this patient. It is mainly 
used for chronic pain. Various routes of administration of fentanyl are: intravenous, epidural, spinal, 
transdermal therapeutic system (transdermal patch and transdermal iontophoresis), oral (buccal 
tablets, films, lozenges).

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is the drug of choice for rescue analgesia?
questions.explanation:
Fentanyl is the drug of choice for providing rescue analgesia. Rescue analgesia involves the use of medications to minimize post-operative pain. Mild pain can 
be controlled with oral analgesics but severe pain requires opioids like fentanyl. Fentanyl is preferred over morphine or oxycodone due to its rapid onset of action, lesser incidence 
of postoperative nausea, vomiting, and other adverse effects.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 60-year-old man was posted for bronchoscopy under procedural sedation. After the 
administration of anesthetic drugs, he developed chest wall rigidity and ineffective 
spontaneous ventilation. Attempts at manual ventilation were unsuccessful due to the 
non-compliant chest wall. The opioid that is most commonly associated with this condition 
is?
questions.explanation:
Chest wall rigidity and ineffective ventilation is a classic presentation of 'wooden chest syndrome'. 
This opioid-induced muscle rigidity is most commonly associated with the use of lipophilic 
opioids such as fentanyl and its congeners (alfentanil, sufentanil, and remifentanil). Risk factors for wooden chest syndrome: 382 
Sold by @itachibot • Rapid administration of a large dose of fentanyl • Concomitant use of nitrous oxide • Old age The clinical presentation can vary from mild hoarseness to chest wall rigidity severe enough to 
prevent adequate bag-and-mask ventilation. Management of wooden chest syndrome: • Discontinuation of the opioid • Replacement of the opioid with a non-lipophilic version (such as hydromorphone or morphine) 
for analgesia • Consider naloxone for reversal (you do not want to reverse analgesia on an intubated patient 
unless absolutely necessary) • Addition of a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker for paralysis • Supportive ventilatory care

questions.question:
Question 12: 374 
Sold by @itachibot Upon recovering from anesthesia, a patient started feeling cold accompanied by shivering. 
Which is the opioid indicated to treat this condition?
questions.explanation:
Meperidine is commonly indicated for post-anesthetic shivering. It prevents post-anesthetic shivering by lowering the temperature threshold at which shivering is 
triggered by the hypothalamus. A single dose of 12.5 to 35mg meperidine (pethidine) is effective in the treatment of postanesthetic 
shivering. Infusion-related chills and rigors associated with amphotericin B, aldesleukin, trastuzumab, and 
alemtuzumab are also managed with meperidine in combination with other agents.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 50-year-old housewife with diabetic nephropathy and receiving dialysis weekly comes to 
your clinic with an accidental burn on her left hand. On examination, 2nd-degree burns are 
seen. Which of the following opioids should not be prescribed to her for analgesia?
questions.explanation:
Pethidine (meperidine) should not be prescribed to her as it is contraindicated in patients 
with renal failure. In renal failure, there is an accumulation of its metabolite norpethidine which causes excitatory 
syndrome consisting of hallucinations, tremors, muscle twitches, and convulsions. Therefore, 
pethidine is avoided in renal failure patients. Methadone, alfentanil, and fentanyl primarily undergo hepatic metabolism.

questions.question:
Question 14: A woman was administered an intravenous opioid for managing postoperative pain. Within 5 
minutes, she started developing severe redness and pruritus along the distribution of the vein 
into which the drug was injected. Which of the following drugs would be responsible for this?
questions.explanation:
The clinical findings are suggestive of histamine release, which is common with the use of 
meperidine (pethidine) due to mast cell activation. 383 
Sold by @itachibot Codeine, morphine, and hydromorphone are also associated with histamine release. Fentanyl, alfentanil, and remifentanil do not lead to histamine release.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 16-year-old boy received an intravenous opioid for analgesia. A few minutes later, his heart 
rate decreased from 72/min to 58/min. Which among the following drugs is least likely to be 
associated with this finding?
questions.explanation:
Meperidine (pethidine) is least likely to be associated with bradycardia. Intravenous meperidine produces tachycardia as it has a structure similar to atropine. Unlike 
other opioids, meperidine causes mydriasis due to its anticholinergic effect. Pentazocine, which is an opioid agonist-antagonist, also produces tachycardia, hypertension, and 
mydriasis.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following opioids has local anesthetic property?
questions.explanation:
The opioid with local anesthetic property is pethidine (meperidine), which is especially seen after 
intrathecal administration. Intrathecal pethidine can provide spinal anesthesia for endoscopic urological procedures and 
surgery of the lower limb, perineum, and lower abdomen including cesarean section. However, due to low potency and systemic opioid side effects, it is usually not used for this 
purpose.

questions.question: Question 17: Apart from mu-opioid receptors, on which other receptor does tramadol act?
questions.explanation:
Tramadol inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine, apart from its action on the 
mu-opioid receptor. It is a synthetic codeine analog that is a mu-opioid receptor agonist. Tramadol is a centrally acting analgesic used in the treatment of mild to moderate pain.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following statements is false regarding tramadol?
questions.explanation:
Tramadol is contraindicated in epileptics. Tramadol is epileptogenic and can cause seizures in predisposed individuals and in those taking 
medications like monoamine oxidase inhibitors and neuroleptic drugs. It is a synthetic analogue of codeine and a weak opioid agonist with 1/6000 affinity for µ receptors 
as that of morphine. Apart from opioid action, it also inhibits the reuptake of 5HT and NE. Due to non-opioid 
receptor-mediated actions, it produces less respiratory depression and less constipation. 384 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 19: A 24-year-old woman requires an intranasal opioid spray for her migraine. Which of the 
following would you prescribe her?
questions.explanation:
Butorphanol is a synthetic opioid available as a nasal spray for use in migraine headaches and 
painful conditions. It is used parenterally as an analgesic for moderate to severe pain or as an adjunct to general 
anesthesia. Opioids available for intranasal administration are butorphanol and fentanyl.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 40-year-old man, on treatment with fluoxetine for depression, was started on an opioid for 
severe neuropathic pain. A few days later he had an episode of syncope and was brought to 
the casualty. ECG taken is given below, with QTc = 477 ms. Which of the following drugs is 
most likely the cause?
questions.explanation:
The given ECG findings show QT prolongation which is associated primarily with the use of 
methadone. In the ECG QTc(corrected QT interval= QT/RR) is 477ms. Normal QTc is about 440ms. Values 
of more than 440ms in males and 460ms in females are considered to be prolonged. QT 
prolongation can present as syncope or cardiac arrest. Methadone has additive action with agents known to cause QT prolongation. Serious cardiac 
arrhythmias including torsades de pointes have been noted with methadone use.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following statements is false regarding methadone?

options.c: Rapidly absorbed from GIT and appears in plasma within 30 min of oral administration
options.d: Onset of analgesia is 30-60 min after parenteral and 1-2 h after oral administration

questions.explanation:
Methadone’s onset of analgesia is 10-20 minutes after the parenteral route, and 30-60 minutes 
after the oral route of administration. Option A: Methadone is a long-acting mu receptor agonist with a plasma half-life of 15-40 hours. Option B: It is an analgesic and used for chronic pain relief. Option C: Absorption from GIT is rapid and appears in plasma within 30 minutes and reaches 
peak concentrations at around 4 hours.

questions.question:
Question 22: A young man is scheduled for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. His medical history is significant 
for depression and he is on monoamine oxidase inhibitors for the same. Which of the 
following opioids can be safely administered to him?
questions.explanation:
Morphine can be safely administered as it does not inhibit the neuronal reuptake of serotonin and 
hence does not trigger serotonin syndrome in patients on MAO inhibitors. Phenylpiperidine series of opioids such as meperidine, tramadol, dextromethorphan, 
and methadone inhibit the neuronal reuptake of serotonin leading to serotonergic overactivity. 
This can cause serotonin syndrome in patients receiving monoamine oxidase inhibitors. 385 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 23: A woman sustained multiple fractures in a motorcycle accident. Her physician prescribed an 
oral opioid for analgesia which is a partial agonist at mu and a full agonist at kappa receptors. 
Identify the drug given.
questions.explanation:
Pentazocine is a partial agonist at mu and a full agonist at kappa receptors. Analgesia produced by pentazocine is predominantly mediated by the  receptor. Pentazocine is a mixed agonist-antagonist opioid agent. It is a full agonist at the  receptor and a 
partial agonist or weak antagonist at the µ receptor. Buprenorphine is a partial agonist at mu receptors but an antagonist at kappa receptors.

questions.question:
Question 24: A cancer patient is dependent on morphine for pain management. His physician decides to 
switch him to buprenorphine. Due to which property he chooses this new drug?
questions.explanation:
Buprenorphine is a partial agonist at the mu receptor with a lower intrinsic activity compared to 
morphine and hence does not produce withdrawal symptoms in patients with morphine 
dependence. Buprenorphine is a synthetic thebaine congener and also acts as an antagonist at kappa receptor. It is more potent than morphine at mu receptor but with lower intrinsic activity and ceiling effect. 
Due to lower intrinsic activity, it has no withdrawal symptoms and can be used in the treatment of 
morphine dependence.

questions.question:
Question 25: An elderly man with bone metastasis is receiving intravenous opioids for pain management. 
Which of the following drugs can be safely administered to him without a risk of developing 
respiratory depression?
questions.explanation:
Buprenorphine can be safely administered to this patient because of its ceiling effect on 
respiratory depression. Ceiling effect is defined as no further increase in the effect of the drug with a further increment in 
dose, once the ceiling level is reached. Opioid agonist-antagonist compounds produce respiratory depression (and analgesia) with a 
ceiling effect which means increasing the dose further does not produce any further respiratory 
depression and may actually result in increased ventilation (due to the predominance of 
antagonist actions). Other drugs that show the ceiling effect are: • Butorphanol • Nalbuphine • Pentazocine. Respiratory depression with morphine, fentanyl & alfentanyl does not have a ceiling effect 
because they are pure opioid agonists. As the dose increases, respiratory depression also increases 
progressing to respiratory arrest. 386 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 26: Which of the following statements is false?
questions.explanation:
Butorphanol is an agonist at  receptor. It may be a partial agonist or antagonist at µ receptor. Pentazocine, butorphanol, buprenorphine, meptazinol, nalorphine, nalbuphine, and dezocine are 
mixed agonist-antagonist opioids. All opioid agonist-antagonists are µ antagonists and k agonists, except buprenorphine, 
pentazocine, and dezocine. Buprenorphine, pentazocine, and dezocine are partial agonists at the  
receptor. Option A: Naltrexone is a pure antagonist at µ, k, and  receptors. Option B: Meperidine is a pure agonist of both  and  receptors. 387 
Sold by @itachibot Opioid Antagonists
